instructions_en:
• Use in otherwise healthy neonates ≥35 weeks gestational age (GA) at the time of discharge. Do not use in neonates with positive direct Coombs test, or in those requiring phototherapy before 60 hours of age. Do not use to determine need for exchange transfusion.

  • The recommendations listed here for starting phototherapy are based on AAP guidelines. Always use clinical judgment, in addition to considering evidence-based clinical guidelines, in making treatment decisions.
search_abbreviation_en: Hour Specific Risk for Neonatal Hyperbilirubinemia
medium_description_en: Predicts risk of hyperbilirubinemia in neonates.

input_schema.name: age
input_schema.tips_en: Use in newborns 12-168 hours of age

input_schema.name: gest
input_schema.tips_en: Optional, for phototherapy recommendations based on AAP guidelines

input_schema.name: factor
input_schema.tips_en: Isoimmune hemolytic disease, G6PD deficiency, asphyxia, significant lethargy, temperature instability, sepsis, acidosis, or albumin <3.0 g/dL (30 g/L)

how_to_use.use_case_en:
• Neonates ≥35 weeks GA at the time of discharge.

  • Do not use in neonates with positive direct Coombs test, or in those requiring phototherapy before 60 hours of age.

  • The recommendations listed here for starting phototherapy are based on AAP guidelines. Always use clinical judgment, in addition to considering evidence-based clinical guidelines, in making treatment decisions.

  • Do not use to determine need for exchange transfusion.
how_to_use.pearls_pitfalls_en:
• Predicts risk of subsequent severe hyperbilirubinemia in neonates ≥35 weeks GA at the time of discharge.

  • Only total serum bilirubin should be used (i.e., not direct or indirect).
how_to_use.why_use_en:
• The American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) recommends risk assessment for developing severe hyperbilirubinemia in every neonate.

  • Helps determine timing for follow up visits.

next_steps.advice_en:
• The risk calculator is one of two clinical options recommended by the AAP for risk assessment (either clinical risk factors alone or in combination with the risk calculator).

  • Most important clinical risk factors to consider include: breastfeeding, GA <38 weeks, significant jaundice in a sibling (defined as requiring phototherapy), and jaundice noted before discharge (Newman 2000).
next_steps.management_en:
• An infant whose predischarge total serum bilirubin is in the low risk zone is at very low risk for developing severe hyperbilirubinemia.

  • Appropriate follow up after discharge must be ensured regardless of method of risk assessment used.

Infant discharged

Should be seen by age

Before 24 hrs

72 hrs

Between 24 and 48 hrs

96 hrs

Between 48 and 72 hrs

120 hrs

From AAP guidelines.
next_steps.critical_actions_en: Clinical judgment should guide follow up. Neonates at higher risk and with clinical risk factors may be followed earlier.

For exact values (starting at 18 hours old), refer to Table 1 in Stevenson 2001.

about.evidence_based_medicine_en:
• The hour specific nomogram was created in 1999 following a study led by Vinod Bhutani. A percentile-based bilirubin nomogram was constructed from hour-specific predischarge and postdischarge total serum bilirubin values of newborns (n = 2,840; median birthweight = 3,230 g and median GA = 39 weeks) for the first week.

  • The study excluded newborns with a positive direct Coombs test or those requiring phototherapy before age 60 hours.

  • The predischarge total serum bilirubin in 61.8% of the newborns (1,756/2,840) was in the low-risk zone (<40th percentile), and there was no measurable risk for significant hyperbilirubinemia (LR = 0; sensitivity = 100%; specificity = 64.7%; probability = 0%).

Validation.text: Stevenson DK, Fanaroff AA, Maisels MJ, et al. Prediction of hyperbilirubinemia in near-term and term infants. Pediatrics. 2001;108(1):31-9.

Original/Primary Reference.text: Bhutani VK, Johnson L, Sivieri EM. Predictive ability of a predischarge hour-specific serum bilirubin for subsequent significant hyperbilirubinemia in healthy term and near-term newborns. Pediatrics. 1999;103(1):6-14.

Other References.text: Newman TB, Xiong B, Gonzales VM, Escobar GJ. Prediction and prevention of extreme neonatal hyperbilirubinemia in a mature health maintenance organization. Arch Pediatr Adolesc Med. 2000;154(11):1140-7.

Clinical Practice Guidelines.text: Management of Hyperbilirubinemia in the Newborn Infant 35 or More Weeks of Gestation Pediatrics. 2004;114(1):297-316.

creator_info.about_en: Vinod K. Bhutani, MD, is a professor of pediatrics (neonatology) at Stanford University School of Medicine and a researcher at the Maternal and Child Health Research Institute in Stanford, CA. He is also the chair and founder of the Global Prevention of Kernicterus. Dr. Bhutani’s primary research is focused on neonatal jaundice biology and management.

seo.meta_description_en: The Hour-Specific Risk for Neonatal Hyperbilirubinemia predicts risk of hyperbilirubinemia in newborns based on total serum bilirubin (TSB) measurement.
seo.keywords_en: Jaundice, neonatal jaundice, tsb, bilirubin, total serum bilirubin, hyperbilirubinemia nomogram, nomogram, hour-specific nomogram, AAP, bilitool, Hour-Specific Risk for Neonatal Hyperbilirubinemia, Hour Specific Risk for Neonatal Hyperbilirubinemia
